![](https://vice-web-statics-cdn.vice.com/images/blank.png)

Erica de Marco, aka Ultimate Whorrior (left) and Gabby Perrea, aka Kunt Fury
(right). © Danielle Scruggs

[Culture](/en_us/topic/culture)

|

by [ Bridjet Mendyuk](/en_us/contributor/bridjet-mendyuk " Bridjet Mendyuk");
photos by [Danielle Scruggs](/en_us/contributor/danielle-scruggs "Danielle
Scruggs")

|

Nov 6 2018, 9:18pm

# Inside an Underground Women's Mud Wrestling Ring in Chicago

## "A couple times when police were called for noise complaints, the cops
would stay and watch."

by [ Bridjet Mendyuk](/en_us/contributor/bridjet-mendyuk " Bridjet Mendyuk");
photos by [Danielle Scruggs](/en_us/contributor/danielle-scruggs "Danielle
Scruggs")

|

Nov 6 2018, 9:18pm

Erica de Marco, aka Ultimate Whorrior (left) and Gabby Perrea, aka Kunt Fury
(right). © Danielle Scruggs

Going to a Chicago [Mud Queens](http://mudqueens.com/) match is a little like
watching the [Netflix show
_G.L.O.W._](https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/mbjyyv/glow-is-netflixs-best-
show-in-years), but with beer, guitars, a much bigger mess, and [less sexual
harassment](https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/pav58y/the-real-women-of-glow-
told-us-the-sexist-bs-they-dealt-with-in-the-80s). The league, which has been
around since 2003, aims to reclaim the raw power of women's mud wrestling,
without the over-sexualized image. What started as a goofy fight among friends
evolved into a legit organization that hosts indoor matches from April through
October at music venues and bars throughout the city. Since 2004, the team has
donated profits from their events to charity.

The provocative, witty, and aggressively [skilled women who sling
mud](https://i-d.vice.com/en_us/article/qvmxjp/great-american-mud-wrestle-
walter-pearce-lily-rose-depp-lotta-volkova) (and occasionally slime, lube, or
spaghetti) at each other have earned the Mud Queens a cult following in
Chicago. The biggest match of the year takes place every Halloween at Reggie’s
Rock Club in Chicago's South Loop. The mud is swapped out for fake blood
(though the recipe for the slick stuff stays secret). It's a combination of
punk rock, feminism, contact sports, and activism that embodies the Windy
City's gritty, DIY ethos.

VICE checked out this year's Halloween event with photographer [Danielle
Scruggs](https://www.instagram.com/dascruggs_/?hl=en) to meet the Mud Queens
and get a behind-the-scenes look at what it takes to throw a bloody good
wrestling match.

## Kira Elliot, a.k.a. Brownie Bruiser

![Kira Elliot, aka Brownie Bruiser](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541521784944-Scruggs_MudQueens-13.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Kira Elliot, aka Brownie Bruiser, is a personal trainer. © Danielle Scruggs

"I’ve been in Mud Queens for eight or nine years. There are a lot of reasons I
do it. My favorite part is the women involved in the organization. They’re
hilarious, and there is an amazing sisterhood in the group. Everybody just
really enjoys each other. We all live these buttoned-up lives, and it’s cool
to let loose and do something that’s off-the-charts wild and crazy. Every
year, after our final show, we give a lump sum of our earnings to the Chicago
Women’s Health Center. I think it’s really important to take care of people,
especially women with reproductive needs. Chicago is competing against New
York and Los Angeles, and there is something gritty about Mud Queens being
here. It gives Chicago a bit more of an edge and reputation of being badass
and hardcore."

## Erica de Marco, a.k.a. Ultimate Whorrior

![Erica de Marco, aka Ultimate Whorrior](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541522512487-Scruggs_MudQueens-54.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Erica de Marco, aka Ultimate Whorrior, is in school for aerospace engineering.
© Danielle Scruggs

“I came to Chicago alone, when I was 21 and didn’t know anybody. I came across
a flyer for a Mud Queens show and texted the founder and said, 'I want to do
this. How do I get trained?' She texted back and said, 'We had a girl drop
out. You're on tomorrow at 7 PM.' She put me up against one of the largest
fighters, and I lost very hard. I lost every fight for the next four years
straight, and it wasn’t until my fifth year that I won my first fight. It’s a
really good feeling when you look out into the audience and people are
cheering. It’s a feeling I’ve grown addicted to. We’re breaking stereotypes.
When you think of mud wrestling, you think of girls rolling around
seductively, but we bring strength to it."

##  Mark Macoun, a.k.a. the Ref

![1541445026255-Scruggs_MudQueens-11](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541445026255-Scruggs_MudQueens-11.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Mark Macoun, aka the referee, is a public servant and one of the original
members of Mud Queens. © Danielle Scruggs

“My buddy Megan wanted to do jello wrestling, but we didn’t know where to
store that much jello, so we made mud. I’ve been doing this since 2003. I’ve
been doing it so long that I don’t know why I would stop [ _laughs_ ]. Mud
Queens is unique to Chicago. We're underground, but we've been around for 15
years. It has to be one of the city's longest running shows at this point. I
love the community aspect—people showing up and putting on a show together—a
band of brothers and sisters, that sort of shit."

## Kim Kozak, a.k.a. El Baño

![Kim Kozak MCs the MudQueens wrestling match](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541525626656-Scruggs_MudQueens-170.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Kim Kozak, aka El Baño, is an audio engineer at Concord Music Hall. © Danielle
Scruggs

“There is nothing else like Mud Queens. It’s badass women who are taking back
mud wrestling. It's a piece of Chicago culture other cities really don't have.
It's a grassroots effort that's badass, crude, and brash—like the city itself.
Our first show was at a birthday party in someone's apartment, put together as
a joke, but everyone had a great time. All of our friends' bands played, and
we started doing more shows from there. The first four or five were stopped by
police. There were a couple times they were called for noise complaints, and
the cops would stay and watch [ _laughs_ ].

"I didn’t think we'd ever be allowed in a legit venue. When we were on loading
docks, we had to move dumpsters and someone was scratched by a rat. It was
pretty ramshackle. We never thought we would ever do a ‘real’ show. We started
charging at the door to make up the money for supplies, and we ended up with
more money than we knew what to do with, so we thought the best thing to do
was give it to charity. The Chicago Women’s Health Center has been our charity
from the start.”

## Ingrid Hansen, a.k.a. Calamity Pain

![Ingrid Hansen, aka Calamity Pain](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541523560799-Scruggs_MudQueens-160.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Ingrid Hansen, aka Calamity Pain, is an account manager for a human resources
company. © Danielle Scruggs

“Before, there was no venue. We wrestled in warehouses or on the street. There
were no real rules. We had rules for safety, but if someone's top fell off, we
weren’t in a public establishment. The costumes have gotten more intricate,
and the organization itself is more organized. We’ve adapted. It was only mud
in the beginning, but the founder created a recipe for blood, and we decided
to use slime. The creative members of Mud Queens are always adding elements to
the show."

## Carly Huizenga, a.k.a. Babe Brute

![Britt Murphy aka the Ovarian Barbarian and Carly Huizenga aka Babe Brute
face off during the MudQueens wrestling match at Reggies Rock Club, October
30, 2018.](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541527651296-Scruggs_MudQueens-95.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Carly Huizenga (right) aka Babe Brute is a senior enterprise account manager
at a startup. She faces off with Britt Murphy (left) aka the Ovarian
Barbarian. © Danielle Scruggs

“There’s a stereotype that women aren’t as strong—that women have inner
strength, but not physical strength. All of us are strong women trying to help
other women. We’re all different sizes and shapes. You are welcome with us.
I’m not a loud person. I’m not very confident in my normal, regular life. That
is completely different when I’m wrestling. I get to push my body and express
all my energy, more than when I'm just working out. After I've let out all
that aggression, I feel calm."

The Mud Queens are always looking for “new blood,” fresh faces, and big
characters. The 2018 season is over, but wrestling will pick back up in the
spring. Follow them on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/mudqueenschicago/)
for more information.

![The full MudQueens troupe on stage at Reggies Rock Club, October 30,
2018](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541532147110-Scruggs_MudQueens-39.jpeg?resize=320:*)

The full Mud Queens troupe on stage at Reggies Rock Club, October 30, 2018. ©
Danielle Scruggs

![1541525749354-Scruggs_MudQueens-15](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541525749354-Scruggs_MudQueens-15.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Pam Turnmire (left) aka Mudusa and Erica de Marco (right) aka Ultimate
Whorrior. © Danielle Scruggs

![Gabby Perrea aka Kunt Fury prepares for her round at the MudQueens wrestling
match at Reggies Rock Club, October 30, 2018.](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541525848915-Scruggs_MudQueens-48.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Gabby Perrea, aka Kunt Fury, prepares for her round. © Danielle Scruggs

![1541444129753-Scruggs_MudQueens-62](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541444129753-Scruggs_MudQueens-62.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Erica de Marco, aka Ultimate Whorrior (left) and Gabby Perrea, aka Kunt Fury
(right) face off. © Danielle Scruggs

![The crowd cheers and watches the MudQueens wrestling match at Reggies Rock
Club, October 30, 2018.](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526179365-Scruggs_MudQueens-58.jpeg?resize=320:*)

The crowd cheers and watches the Mud Queens wrestling match at Reggies Rock
Club, October 30, 2018. © Danielle Scruggs

![The crowd cheers and watches the MudQueens wrestling match at Reggies Rock
Club, October 30, 2018.](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526226310-Scruggs_MudQueens-67.jpeg?resize=320:*)

The crowd cheers and watches the Mud Queens wrestling match at Reggies Rock
Club, October 30, 2018. © Danielle Scruggs

![Annie Hartlepape \(left\) aka Red Witch and Emily McGlawn aka Betty
Brickhouse face off at Reggies Rock Club, October 30, 2018.](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526290543-Scruggs_MudQueens-70.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Annie Hartlepape (left), aka Red Witch, and Emily McGlawn (right), aka Betty
Brickhouse, face off at Reggies Rock Club, October 30, 2018. © Danielle
Scruggs

![1541526367112-Scruggs_MudQueens-72](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526367112-Scruggs_MudQueens-72.jpeg?resize=320:*)

The crowd cheers and watches the Mud Queens wrestling match at Reggies Rock
Club, October 30, 2018. © Danielle Scruggs

![1541526450900-Scruggs_MudQueens-85](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526450900-Scruggs_MudQueens-85.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Laura Leigh Smith aka Maiden Hell and Frida Killahoe face off during the Mud

Scruggs

![1541526591557-Scruggs_MudQueens-163](https://video-

The crowd cheers and watches the MudQueens wrestling match at Reggies Rock

![1541526585302-Scruggs_MudQueens-151](https://video-

Ingrid Hansen (right) aka Calamity Pain, wins a round. © Danielle Scruggs

![1541526568111-Scruggs_MudQueens-138](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526568111-Scruggs_MudQueens-138.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Lisa Weeber aka Queen Cock Block acts as a ring girl during the Mud Queens
wrestling match at Reggies Rock Club, October 30, 2018. © Danielle Scruggs

![1541526533825-Scruggs_MudQueens-88](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526533825-Scruggs_MudQueens-88.jpeg?resize=320:*)

The crowd cheers and watches the Mud Queens wrestling match at Reggies Rock
Club, October 30, 2018. © Danielle Scruggs

![1541443576548-Scruggs_MudQueens-108](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541443576548-Scruggs_MudQueens-108.jpeg?resize=320:*)

Kira Elliot, aka Brownie Bruiser, hoses off after the match. © Danielle
Scruggs

![1541526636528-Scruggs_MudQueens-174](https://video-
images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1541526636528-Scruggs_MudQueens-174.jpeg?resize=320:*)

© Danielle Scruggs

![1541526647494-Scruggs_MudQueens-176](https://video-
